entries.content: Start a cold call by giving the prospect control and explicit permission to hang up or give you a short timeframe.
entries.notes: Increases the chance of getting a few seconds; counter-intuitive disarming technique.

entries.content: "You can absolutely hang up right now... Or, if you can give me just 20 or 30 seconds..."
entries.notes: Example phrase for permission-based opening in a cold call.

entries.content: When facing price objections, probe deeper to understand the context rather than arguing the price directly.
entries.notes: Helps uncover the real objection, expectation, or alternative.

entries.content: "Okay, too expensive compared to what?" or "What were you expecting to invest?"
entries.notes: Examples of questions used to probe price objections.

entries.content: Consciously control your vocal tone to convey confidence, curiosity, and a genuine willingness to help.
entries.notes: Avoid sounding pushy or overly scripted. Tone is part of delivery technique.

entries.content: Adopt a mindset of curiosity during sales interactions.
entries.notes: Supports effective questioning and genuine tone.

entries.content: In discovery calls, use strategic silence after asking an open-ended question.
entries.notes: Encourages the prospect to share more valuable information by filling the silence.

entries.content: Clearly define and state the agreed-upon next step at the end of every sales interaction.
Get explicit agreement from the prospect on the defined next steps before concluding the interaction.
entries.notes: Ensures buy-in and clarity on path forward.

entries.content: "Does that sound like a good plan for you?"
entries.notes: Example phrase used to confirm agreement on next steps.
